user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DirCreate_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_DirCreate_Impl(const char *local_path, uint32 access)
{
    struct stat st;
    int32       return_code;

    if (mkdir(local_path, S_IFDIR | S_IRWXU | S_IRWXG | S_IRWXO) < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;

        if (errno == EEXIST)
        {
            /* Success if already exists and is a directory */
            if (stat(local_path, &st) == 0 && S_ISDIR(st.st_mode))
            {
                return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            }
        }
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_DirCreate_Impl:
int32 OS_mkdir(const char *path, uint32 access)
{
    int32 return_code;
    char  local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];

    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(path, local_path);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_DirCreate_Impl(local_path, access);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I have reported all conditional/control-flow fragments where code might be effectively unreachable and therefore should be investigated for compliance with MISRA C Rule 2.1: the whole mkdir() error/success branch (including the errno == EEXIST sub-branch and the stat()/S_ISDIR check) and the caller-side conditional in OS_mkdir that only invokes OS_DirCreate_Impl when OS_TranslatePath returns OS_SUCCESS. These locations are the only places where control flow determines whether particular statements execute; they therefore are the relevant spots for potential unreachable code.

Other parts of the provided code need not be investigated for unreachable-code concerns: the function prologues, local variable declarations (struct stat st; int32 return_code; char local_path[...] ), the final 'return return_code;' statements, and the macro definitions for OS_SUCCESS and OS_ERROR are ordinary elements and do not by themselves create unreachable regions. The single unused parameter 'access' is a potential maintenance/quality issue but is not evidence of unreachable code and thus was not selected. The direct call to mkdir(...) (the call expression itself) is the entry point for the conditional I flagged above and does not need separate investigation beyond that conditional.
